title: Optimizing Care for Patients With Dementia: A Comparison of Two Non-pharmacological Treatment Approaches
description_brief:
Of the 1.4 million nursing home (NH) residents in long term care facilities, more than half have Alzheimer's disease or dementia. Due to changes in their familiar daily routines, difficulty expressing their thoughts or asking for what they need, and overstimulation (such as noise) or under stimulation (such as lack of activity), individuals with dementia often display disruptive behaviors like resisting help or continually repeating the same phrases. Medications are often prescribed to reduce agitation and aggressive behavior; however, these medications may not be effective and can have a negative impact on the individual. Therefore, families and other stakeholders strongly advocate the use of other types of approaches that focus on minimizing the cause of the behavior. Two facility-based methodologies include the transdisciplinary approach for integrated dementia care, which combines the expertise of all NH staff, who work together to build a common language and approach for each resident, and the multidisciplinary approach for problem-based dementia care, in which each staff member conducts individual assessments and makes discipline-specific recommendations. While prior research suggests that both of these facility-based approaches are useful, the circumstances under which each approach is most effective are not clear. This project will prospectively randomize 80 nursing homes to one of the two treatment arms to compare the effect of the transdisciplinary approach versus the multidisciplinary approach.

This study will examine the difference between the two comparators with respect to facility rates of medications dispensed to residents with dementia, leading to enhanced quality of life for the resident.

This project is important because it will address a key clinical dilemma NH staff face as they strive to optimize the use of alternative approaches to reduce disruptive behaviors in residents with dementia. Transforming the quality of dementia care in NHs and enhancing the quality of life of residents with dementia are high priorities for families and other advocates.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: This mixed methods study used quantitative methods to examine nursing home resident outcomes of the two non-pharmacological approaches to dementia care (i.e., the primary study outcomes). Qualitative methods included one-time interviews with family caregivers and nursing home staff intended to understand their experiences with the two non-pharmacological approaches. Flow chart below reflects the participating nursing homes (i.e., units) and their residents with dementia (i.e. participants).

groups.title: Transdisciplinary Approach
groups.description: This approach is integrated across disciplines and provides core training for all providers, staff members, and stakeholders, using a common language to address care concerns and support continuity and sustainability;

groups.title: Multidisciplinary Approach
groups.description: This is a problem-based approach that draws on the expertise of individual healthcare providers (e.g., occupational therapy) to address care concerns.

baselineCharacteristicsModule.populationDescription: This was a nursing home-level analysis, therefore not all participants were in the sample during the baseline period. Participants (i.e., nursing home residents) were included if they met the study criteria based on age, dementia status, and long-term nursing home residence, but could be included in the sample at any point of the study. Thus, there were participants who were in the study sample (and reflected in the flow overview), but were not in the study sample during the baseline period.

measures.title: Nursing Home Occupancy Rate
measures.unitOfMeasure: # of occupied beds/ # of certified beds

measures.title: CMS Nursing Home Rating
measures.description: This is the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid (CMS) 5-Star Rating for nursing homes, which is a composite measure of quality reflecting state survey performance, staffing, and quality. The measure ranges from 1 to 5, with a score of 1 indicating low care quality and 5 indicates high care quality.

outcomeMeasures.title: Dispensing of Psychotropic Medications
outcomeMeasures.description: Percentage of nursing home residents with dementia who received one or more antipsychotic medication over Months 1-6 of Intervention.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Population includes all nursing home residents with dementia in participating nursing homes with valid data in the Minimum Data Set (MDS) assessments.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: This pragmatic clinical trial was embedded into the workflow of the nursing homes. Our intervention was about training staff about dementia knowledge. We were not intervening at patient level, thus adverse outcomes were not relevant.
adverseEventsModule.description: This pragmatic clinical trial was embedded into the workflow of the nursing homes. Our intervention was about training staff about dementia knowledge. We were not intervening at patient level, thus adverse outcomes were not relevant.

eventGroups.title: Transdisciplinary Approach
eventGroups.description: This approach is integrated across disciplines and provides core training for all providers, staff members, and stakeholders, using a common language to address care concerns and support continuity and sustainability;

eventGroups.title: Multidisciplinary Approach
eventGroups.description: This is a problem-based approach that draws on the expertise of individual healthcare providers (e.g., occupational therapy) to address care concerns.

limitationsAndCaveats.description: We were only able to assess post-training outcomes for 6 months prior to COVID-19 and it is possible that nursing homes would have achieved different outcomes after this initial start-up period. Similarly, the comparative effectiveness of the care approaches in 12- and 18-month follow-up period were confounded by the effects of COVID-19. Finally, the use of antipsychotic medication outcome was collected with a 7-day look back period, which may have resulted in underreporting.

explanation_target: Reason: The trial randomizes nursing homes to two non-pharmacological care models (a transdisciplinary/team-based approach vs a multidisciplinary/problem-based approach) to reduce disruptive behaviors (e.g., agitation, rejection of care, wandering) and to lower rates of psychotropic/antipsychotic medication dispensing. citeturn0search3turn0search4

Act: Key extracted details — Interventions: 'transdisciplinary approach' and 'multidisciplinary approach' (facility-based, non-drug). The study explicitly measures antipsychotic/psychotropic medication dispensing and behavioral outcomes; no investigational drug or placebo is involved. citeturn0search0turn0search7

Reflect: Because the interventions are behavioral/organizational (non-pharmacologic) and aim to manage neuropsychiatric/behavioral symptoms of dementia and reduce psychotropic medication use, the correct category is 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' rather than a disease-targeted biologic/small molecule or a cognitive enhancer. This classification aligns with the published protocol and results describing the cluster randomized trial of team- vs problem-based nonpharmacologic dementia care. citeturn0search4turn0search9

Web search results / sources consulted (titles shown with citations): 'Optimizing Care for Patients With Dementia' (trial registry entry, NCT03442322). citeturn0search3turn0search0; 'Evaluating non-pharmacological approaches to nursing home dementia care: A protocol' (PubMed/article describing the trial design). citeturn0search4; 'A Cluster Randomized Trial: Mixed Methods Comparison of 2 Approaches to Promote Nonpharmacologic, Resident-Centered Dementia Care in Nursing Homes' (trial outcomes/publication summary). citeturn0search9; Rehabilitation Health Services Research Laboratory study summary. citeturn0search2.
explanation_agent: Reason: The study randomizes nursing homes to two non-pharmacological care models (team-/transdisciplinary vs problem-/multidisciplinary) to reduce disruptive behaviors and lower psychotropic/antipsychotic dispensing — the intervention is behavioral/organizational, not a drug or biologic. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: Key extracted details — Interventions: 'transdisciplinary/team-based' and 'multidisciplinary/problem-based' (facility-based, non-drug). Primary outcomes include percent of residents receiving antipsychotic/psychotropic medications and behavioral outcomes (wandering, rejection of care, behavioral symptoms). No investigational drug, molecular target, gene, or pathway is specified in the trial registry or publications. citeturn1search0turn0search1

Reflect: CADRO is organized around biological/mechanistic targets (e.g., amyloid, tau, inflammation, synaptic plasticity). Because this trial tests non-pharmacologic care-delivery models aimed at neuropsychiatric symptom management and medication reduction rather than a biological target or therapeutic compound, the correct CADRO assignment is 'T) Other' (non-therapeutic/organizational intervention). This classification aligns with the published protocol and cluster-randomized trial reporting. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Web search results consulted (representative):
- Protocol: 'Evaluating non-pharmacological approaches to nursing home dementia care: A protocol' (PubMed) — describes the cluster randomized comparison of team- vs problem-based non-pharmacologic ADRD care. citeturn0search0
- Trial publication: 'A Cluster Randomized Trial: Mixed Methods Comparison of 2 Approaches to Promote Nonpharmacologic, Resident-Centered Dementia Care in Nursing Homes' (PubMed) — reports outcomes including antipsychotic use, behavioral symptoms, wandering, rejection of care. citeturn0search1
- Trial registry summary (NCT03442322 / Optimizing Care for Patients With Dementia) — lists interventions as 'multidisciplinary' and 'transdisciplinary' (other/non-drug) and primary outcomes measuring psychotropic medication dispensing and behavioral outcomes. citeturn1search0
